description: Master the rhythmic three-step cycle of Test-Driven Development to build robust and maintainable software

slides.title: The TDD Rhythm
slides.content:
# Red-Green-Refactor ğŸ¥

This cycle is the heartbeat of professional software craftsmanship. It ensures that every line of code is necessary, tested, and clean.

slides.title: Step 1: RED ğŸ”´
slides.content:
# Thinking First ğŸ”´

Write a test for the next bit of functionality you want to add.

- **Must Fail**: If it passes, your test isn't checking anything new!
- **Assertion**: Start with the `Assert` (What is the outcome?).

slides.title: The Meaning of Failure
slides.content:
# Good Failures âŒ

A test can fail because:
- The function doesn't exist (Reference Error).
- The function returns the wrong value.
- It throws an exception erroneously.

> ğŸ’¡ "Failure is information. It tells you exactly what to implement next."

slides.title: Step 2: GREEN ğŸŸ¢
slides.content:
# Minimum Effort ğŸŸ¢

Make the test pass. Just that. Nothing more.

- **Sin of Anticipation**: Do not implement extra features "just in case".
- **Quick and Dirty**: It's okay if the code is a bit messy here; we have a plan for it.

slides.quizQuestion: In the RED phase, if your new test immediately passes, what should you do?
quizOptions: Determine why it passed and ensure the test is actually valid
slides.title: Phase Quiz
slides.content: Unexpected success.

slides.title: Hardcoding to Green
Forcing Logic
Step 3: REFACTOR ğŸ”µ
slides.content:
# Cleaning Up ğŸ”µ

Now that you have a green safety net, improve the design.

- **Check for**: Duplication (DRY), clarity, performance.
- **Rules**: Internal structure changes only. **External behavior must NOT change**.

slides.title: Refactoring Examples
slides.content:
# Better Code âœ¨

- Rename `cnt` to `userCount`.
- Extract a complex `if` block into a named helper function.
- Move repeating logic into a shared class.

slides.quizQuestion: What allows you to refactor code confidently in the third phase?
slides.title: Safety Quiz
slides.content: The safety net.

slides.title: The Golden Rule of Refactoring
slides.content:
# One at a time â˜ï¸

Never refactor and add features at the same time. 

- **Refactor**: Stay in Green.
- **New Feature**: Go to Red.

slides.title: The Refactoring Mindset
slides.content:
# Scout Rule â›º

> "Always leave the code cleaner than you found it."

Each TDD cycle is an opportunity to pay back small amounts of technical debt.

slides.title: Skipping Refactor?
slides.content:
# Technical Debt ğŸ›‘

If you skip the Refactor step repeatedly, your code will rot. You'll end up with "tested spaghetti code", which is hard to read and hard to change.

slides.title: Verification vs Design
slides.content:
# Design Tool ğŸ¨

Remember: Red-Green is for **verification**. Refactor is for **design**. Both are equally critical for a healthy project.

slides.quizQuestion: Which phase is specifically dedicated to improving the internal structure of code without changing its external behavior?
slides.title: Objective Quiz
slides.content: Identifying goals.

slides.title: Handling Breaking Tests
slides.content:
# Regression ğŸ”™

If a refactor causes a test to turn Red, you made a mistake! Undo the change and try a smaller, safer refactor step.

slides.title: Small Refactors
slides.content:
# Atomicity âš›ï¸

Large refactors should be broken into tiny steps. Move a method. Run tests. Rename a variable. Run tests. Move a class. Run tests.

slides.title: Performance Tuning
slides.content:
# Speeding Up ğŸï¸

Refactoring is also when you optimize slow logic. Since you already have the tests, you can swap an $O(N^2)$ algorithm for an $O(log N)$ one safely.

slides.title: Naming Things
slides.content:
# Clarity ğŸ·ï¸

Spend your refactoring time on better names. Code is read thousands of times more than it is written. Make it clear!

slides.quizQuestion: When should you write a new test?
quizOptions: When you want to add new behavior
Only after a bug is reported
slides.title: Final Quiz
slides.content: Continuing the cycle.

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Summary ğŸ‰

- âœ… **Green**: Satisfy the requirements with minimum code.
